prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the scenario (the author) is in the wrong. The situation involves the author's husband setting up his home office in their bedroom despite being offered the basement. The husband works mostly on conference calls, so the author ends up having to manage the kids and household tasks to keep the bedroom quiet. This limits her ability to do chores, take a shower, nap, etc. The author feels that by choosing the bedroom, the husband is causing more disruption, and she's justified in not guaranteeing silence. The husband thinks she's the problem for not keeping quiet. The question is whether the author is at fault (A) or not (B).

First, I need to consider what the author did. She suggested the basement as an alternative, which would have less disruption. The husband refused, choosing the bedroom for the view. The author then communicates that she can't promise silence if he stays in the bedroom. So, she's setting a boundary based on the husband's choice. Is she wrong for not keeping the bedroom undisturbed if he's opted to work there despite knowing the implications?

The husband's job requires quiet, but he made the choice to set up where disturbances are more likely. The author is managing the household, including kids, which is part of her role. By not forcing herself to create a silent environment (which might be impractical given kids and chores), is she at fault? The key point is that the husband's decision to work in the bedroom impacts her ability to function. She's not the one causing the disturbances; the kids and chores are. She's already making compromises by allowing him to work there, but the choice to be in the bedroom is his. Therefore, she's not in the wrong for not guaranteeing silence because he's elected to work in a space that's more prone to disturbances. The answer would be B.
